content.description: A <math alttext="2 kilogram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> block on a horizontal surface is attached to a horizontal spring of negligible mass. The other end of the spring is attached to a wall, and there is negligible friction between the block and the horizontal surface. The block is released from rest after the spring is stretched such that the block-spring system experiences simple harmonic motion, as shown in the graph that represents the block’s velocity as a function of time.
content.question: How could a student use the known information and the graph to determine the magnitude of the change in spring potential energy of the system from the release point of the block to the moment when the system’s spring potential energy is zero?

choices.label: By determining the kinetic energy of the block at <math alttext="8 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>8</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> by using <math alttext="K equals, one half m times v squared" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>K</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><msup><mrow><mi>m</mi><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>.

By determining the kinetic energy of the block at <math alttext="2 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and 6 s by using <math alttext="K equals, one half m times v squared" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>K</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><msup><mrow><mi>m</mi><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and adding the two values of kinetic energy together.
